reviewText:
This is the worst coded game I have ever played on any system. It is full of bugs, to say the least. The jumping is clumsy, at best, and you will commonly find yourself missing jumps due to the poor input response, or the character was too far over the edge, or I really don't know because the jump timings constantly seem to be changing... Other, more rare, times you bug out and jump farther and overshoot everything, (including your wildest imagination). There is also a random delay that can occur as well, which becomes very troublesome considering the tedious and unforgiving circumstances which the game puts you into like having to press B quickly before the wind picks up and O NO TOO LATE YOUR BUTTON DELAYED AND YOU FELL INTO THAT PIT. No worries, LET'S RESPAWN YOU RIGHT AS THE WIND IS BLOWING SO YOU DON'T EVEN HAVE A CHANCE THIS TIME. (Good thing they add checkpoints about every 3 jumps or so or I would have uninstalled long before 2.5 hours.)

Add to that a terrible control for aiming the bola, lag (in an offline game wtf?!, My computer is way more than able to run a game like this.), and repetitive chase scenarios where they give you no spare time and basically force you to fail repeatedly if you do not know what lies ahead (this is where the random delays become most terrible), and you have a completely frustrating and aggravating experience.  The fun parts of this game are short-lived as you are suddenly reminded why it is so bad with some misfortune. I'm kind of just into it now to see the rest of the unlockable videos.

The puzzles are not satisfying, they are cruel and tedious given the poor controls. Honestly, they should have just made a  cultural documentary and cut out this bug-ridden horribly coded game that, minus the antropological aspect, is a less than mediocre platformer.

Did anyone playtest this thing before release? 2/5, 1 point for the concept and raising awareness, and 1 for making that money. Upset: yes. Buy this game: for < $5 if you have a good sense of humor about all the fails you will make.

reviewText:
Now, I'm not the biggest fan of platform games. I used to have pretty much no choice but to play them having grown up with the likes of Sonic The Hedgehog and Super Mario World, but never did have any real patience or skill, 3D platformers made that a lot easier later on, like with Spyro the Dragon and those became bigger favourites, though still far from my most favourite genre (if I can ever decide what that is! I love RPGs, but RPGs can be platformers, point & click, FPS...)

Still, having won this game over at SteamGifts[www.steamgifts.com] from a kind user giving away a copy (I've given away well over a hundred games myself too, all different.) I entered a couple of others before winning, as you do, but only enter for games I believe I will eventually play fairly, either to completion or at least invest a few hours, no matter how long that takes.

Never Alone somehow quickly rose to the top of my play list. I'd heard good things about its play style, characters, art style... You name it. In-particular stories from why others had it on their wishlists, which would vary from wanting the trading cards to loving the idea of playing the fox. One person even commented they'd planned to play with their younger brother, but had kept arguing over who'd play who! Numa or the Fox.

Advertised as co-op, I had no idea how would play both characters at once, but the AI was (mostly) top-notch, a little silly at some points, but it was easy to swap between characters, and many of the puzzles were interesting, fun and requiring a little thought, usually just to slow down and think them through. It even kept me interested for the entire time I played, though my heart skipped a beat at one scene when the Manhunter snaps the foxes' neck. This is completely unavoidable, and story related, but heart crunching, even though he does come back almost immediately with new powers, a reborn spirit.

The added short videos are well worth watching too, for they tell the story of the Alaskan natives and how they have survived in that environment. Their culture, history and how they live in their communities, in many respects, a lesson much of the world also needs to learn once more.

In short, we'd break this down into positives and negatives.

POSITIVE Great Artwork Style with realistic movement in both animal and human.
Innovative puzzles ranging from the usual timing of movements to having to use the weather to your advantage.
HD Quality Mini-Movies, telling the history of the Alaskan Natives and a bit of extra backstory into the actual scenario
Easily played both in single-player & co-op mode. I hadn't even tried with another person, but did setup so I could control both at once for one or two levels just to practice for fun.
Story. The story itself is relatively short and simple in practice, yet it holds an important lesson that can be interprated in different ways, all to a positive. Myself I took away that even the weakest, or most unlikely, person can make a a true difference. Nuna was but a small girl, yet she braved what the others would not. Ever curious about the blizzard threatening her village.
NEGATIVES Missing elements to the story. Such as why the Man-Hunter, or at least the Iñupiat version of the Big Bad Wolf, wanted Nuna's Bola, and how he hadn't found it from the Owl Man. Or how her village, supposedly destroyed by him, was inhabitated again once she had returned, fleeing from the Ice Giant.. I went back to the relevant chapters 2~3 times, and viewed ALL the cinematics, but could not find answers to these.
Some may disagree, in fact I'm sure many will. But I'd unfortunately have to place the Soundtrack here. If there was much of a soundtrack at all, I'd have missed it entirely. It did not stand out for me at all, had any played. Mainly only during cinematic movies, or one time at the village. Not any kind of obvious or consistent soundtrack.
Some very minor bugs, intermitantly appearing. Fox sounding like Nuna when jumping or injured on occasion, for instance. Or later into the game Nuna appearing to float" in mid air
date: when she would ordinarily fall right away
recommended: notably after using the wind to "power" jump.\n4 Achievements requiring additional purchase of the Foxtales DLC. I don't know if they could be set to only show up with the DLC installed or not
hoursPlayed: but this is kinda off-putting.\nOverall
voteText: I definitely can recommend the game. It stands out to me as a game suitable for those both experienced and new to the platforming genre looking for something a little more casual yet addicting."

reviewText:
Lets break this one down a bit.

Mechanically, it was mostly okay. It plays a bit like Limbo, albeit a little less polished. There were a few instances of the game glitching me to my death which frustrated me, but the checkpoint system in this game is very forgiving so I wasn't set too far back.

Artistically, it was very unique. The visuals are obviously heavily influenced by native Alaskan culture. I wasn't particularly enthralled by it, but at the very least, it's nice to see some cultural diversity in my game.

The narrative is, again, very cultural. That being said, it's rather bland. I never felt all that invested in the characters or the outcome of things to come.

Overall, the game is nice. Nothing particularly bad about it, but it fails to grab me in any significant way. And while the cultural insights" tend to be fairly interesting
date: it tends to more often feel like it hurts the pacing of the game if you watch them as you get them. This is probably a really good game to get if you're interested in learning a bit about Alaskan Native culture. But if you're looking for a game to get something more out of

reviewText:
This was very nice, however I couldn't help but feel a bit cheated.

Beautiful game, wonderful gameplay, yet I couldn't tell why it felt so short.

Then it dawned on me. Every now and again I would make progress and a notification about more videos would come up, and after a short time it began to make sense. This game wasn't just a short game, it wanted me to watch videos throughout and learn about the Far North.

I mean, this is cool and all, and totally a new twist, but I as a gamer I want to be immersed in a game, not have the spell broken every new level just to watch a video of real people and real history.

It is worth a shot, it is kinda fun, but I would think watching a playthrough of it may be better suited, as it is a lot shorter than expected.

positive:
it's a visually pleasing game and the graphical aspect is a good representative of the atmospheric environment the developers aimed for. i also appreciate the cultural insight which shows the motive behind this game as well as the heart put into it. additonally, the bond between nuna and the fox is quite nice- i enjoyed that since i love foxes.

---------

negative:
about a year ago, i gave this game roughly an hour of gameplay, but became increasingly frustrated by technicalities that made it tedious which resulted in me taking a long break.

i recently decided to give it another try, launched it and found that my saves were gone. luckily, i never got too far into the game anyway so it wasn't that big of a deal. i thought that maybe starting it anew wasn't such a bad idea to see if i still held the same stance towards what i've already played.

it was a little better than i remembered it, but that didn't last long...

it's surprising that a game like this, a platformer involving a quick switch between two characters, doesn't maintain seamless gameplay as a top priority. it's by no means unplayable, but getting through it shouldn't have to be a chore. i don't think it's intentionally difficult, but coordination becomes exhausting and frustrating due to glitches. i also think that the gameplay tends to feel repetitive after a while.

i still haven't finished the game because i left off on yet another bug where nuna was stuck on the ground and i didn't want to bother with restarting that task. at this point, i'm not sure if or when i'll revisit it.

sorry, wish i had more pleasant memories of this game, but what i mostly remember is how many times i nearly gave up on it.

reviewText:
Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a very cute game that offers a lot of story and history. It explores the culture of the Iñupiat people (Alaskan Natives) and, specifically, the story of nature and its massive influence upon the world. As you explore the amazing landscape that has been laid out before you, you will begin to appreciate the intensity and dedication to quality in which the Iñupiat have presented this game. Not only does it offer stunning graphics, but it provides such a storytelling that you may sometimes question whether it even is a game at all. Please do not, however, let that deter you from purchasing this. This can easily be classified as a documentary within a game, and I believe that a lot more 'games' like this should be created. Not only does it let you explore a culture, it also educates you on the beauty of the world and what it truly has to offer.

Pros+  Very educational game that I believe most people should try out
+  The music is satisfying enough; the sound effects are just as good as well
+  You get to play as a tiny little fox... and it is absolutely amazing. Believe me
+  Achievements are easy enough to achieve, however some are locked behind a $3.99 pricetag (DLC)
+  The game has nice narration and works to provide as much background as possible in a visually pleasing way
+  Offers a unique style of gameplay: you're able to play as two different characters; careful planning is necessary
+  Educational Cultural Insights" can be picked up throughout the game; perhaps it is my love for history

reviewText: A beautiful creation, but the gameplay mechanics make it nearly possible to become immersed. To call it buggy is a gross understatement. This game feels very unpolished and is borderline unplayable--between the significant lag, glitched jumps, and outrageously bugged climbing mechanic, I struggle to get through what should be very simple barriers. There have also been several times in which the fox inexplicably slid straight down through the ground and died.\n\nI was very much looking forward to Kisima Ingitchuna because of the Limbo-esque platform and puzzle style. However, the gameplay is such a huge turnoff that I deeply regret purchasing it. Would love to revisit and replay it if the bugs are ever corrected. Otherwise, I really can't recommend this game.

reviewText:
Just finished the game. I'll start with the cons, because for me they outweighted the pros.

Cons:
- Unfriendly controls (especially if you're playing it in a single-player mode)
- Story lacking any kind of sense (even fairytale one)
- Unclear in-game tutorials (e.g. how to unlock all the cultural insights)

Pros:
- Nice visual design
- Still a good story
- Cultural insights (an easy way to learn something new, something you wouldn't have even tried learning otherwise)

Seems like 3 to 3, right? No. You can strike the last one out, because you are VERY likely to unlock only the most of them, but not all. And you wouldn't even realise what you did or didn't do wrong. The game simply tells you NOTHING about the process of unlocking cultural insights. Yes, you can see it for yourself that they're triggered by being close to that owl. But no clue as to where you should look for it -  sometimes you jump there and you're dead, sometimes it's a hidden path.

Also, Foxtales DLC should have been made free (and the devs actually promised it to be free, but here we are). The game is short already. not including it was really nasty.

reviewText:
First off, only buy this game if it is on sale and just be aware, it's an educational/puzzle game.

+ GFX look beauftiful
+ Great atmosphere
+ The story is pretty good, based off an old story from a Northern Alaskan people(eskimo)
+ Controls are fine
+ Character sprites are awesome
+ Best educational game I've ever played

- Game is too easy, as in, the puzzles are really simple
- No required replay(you can get everything in one play through)
- A tad glitchy. Rarely, characters can get caught in the wall when jumping, then fall to their death
- Not worth full price
- Too short, beat it in less than 3 hours

Overall, it is enjoyable and unique, get it when it is on sale.

reviewText:
I actually liked the way this game started out, and had fun playing co-op with my sister. Then the bolas came into play. Holding back on the right controller stick and then firing was just clunky, and it really showed during a chase scene. The bolas should have been charged with another button press and then fired using the stick as aiming.

The fact the vibration setting caused the bolas to work on opposite day didn't sit right with me either. Once I turned it off, it was alright.

Otherwise it was really fun for the short time we played it. Just the bolas ruined it.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is gorgeous. Not once did it disappoint visually, the style was fun and imaginative with the storytelling sets vivifying an esnaring tale.

As a game, you know, the kind you play, I can not recommend it. The gameplay is repetitive, unchallenging, and the controls frustrate quickly. I can't imagine much time was spent on the multiplayer at any interval because the camera nearly made my cohort and I enemies, and we survived Mario Party.

The gameplay shifts amusingly mid-way through the story, a stunt that many games have failed to pull off.

I'm afraid the interactive portions of this game just weep poor design. Understanding the parts of the environment you can interact with is easy enough, but collision detection is shaky at best, the response time and restrictions on controls would have left a body trail a mile long, but we couldn't finish the game. I'm sorry to say that the compelling visual style and thrust of the culture was not enough to mitigate a tepid gaming experience.

this type of games usually attractive for me so for sure I am going to say it's good game even if ppl doesn't like it, but there was something so special about it that I've never seen in any other game...

so this game is not only about playing if you like documentaries you may like to watch those short videos they were well made & so fun to watch

reviewText:
Great game despite a few faults in the game's engine and companion AI.

Pros: Great puzzle-platformer with a rich story and a lot of background in the insights. Definitely for anyone who wants to relax a little and enjoy a story while also having to think through a few puzzles. The Co-Op also makes for a great way to spend some time with a friend to solve puzzles and just relax.

Cons: The AI just needs a tighter leash to the main player and more danger-awareness so that players are not having to quick-swap to avoid the constant dangers that there are. Also, being able to throw the bola without having to dead-stop would help a lot in chase sequences where stopping dead just to aim kills half the time. The only other issue I see is dropping boxes on the other companion doesn't KILL them but makes the boxes, which are already slightly glitchy and hard to move around sometimes, now impossible to move period.

Overall: 8.5/10. I would definitely give it a 10 but some of these issues make progressing challenging or impossible for annoying lengths of time.

reviewText:
I feel ripped off and I want my money back.

The Cons: This game has a myriad of problems holding it back from being just a mediocre experience.  It's insanely buggy.  Characters have gone through wall collisions on more than one occasion. Platforms sometimes don't trigger and the fox AI is really really dumb to the point where it's frusterating. The game also suffers from clunky player controls which in my experience is standard unity powered games (Is that the default player input script???). I want to support indies but make your game work!

Even if the bugs were fixed, the gameplay is quite boring. The platforming elements are lackluster and the game lacks any other mechanics asides from the bola to solve 'puzzles'. There's no variety, there's no gradual and continuous introduction of mechanics to keep me interested. You get all the tools you need within the first hour of the game and that's it.

The Pros: The artwork and theme is pretty nice. The educational snippits saved the game. I had something to work towards. Rarely do I support breaking up the flow of gameplay, but the videos in this situation broke up the monotony.

Overall, it pains me to say, but pass on this game. If the theme really grabs you, then wait for a sale.This game is way too expensive to justify what is delivered.

reviewText: Such a beautiful game. I played the Fox tales DLC as well and thoroughly enjoyed it. It is a wonderful tribute to the Inupiat culture that not many people know much about; a culture that is very close to nature. I love how it bases the story off Inupiat folk tales. It makes me want to hear more, and I love how you get the video insights at intervals to give you more interesting facts. The gameplay itself is enjoyable and challenging although in some parts the controls were slightly off or lagging, but never so much to distract me from the overall immersive and fun storyline. Certainly some parts I had to replay a few times before I got it as it was challenging but you have to expect that from a game, and it certainly felt rewarding to complete each section. I played using a playstation controller synced up to my PC and I found that this was a great combination for enjoyable gameplay. I would not have called this game tedious in the slightest, but then some people lack imagination. I will always back this.

reviewText: Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is an indie puzzle platformer that brings some interesting concepts and ideas to the table, telling a story from Iñupiaq cultures. However while the art and story are superb, everything else is not. Platforming is slow and clunky, and I would find myself dying over and over because mechanics were either not clear or not working right at all.\n\nTo put it short, if the culture interests you greatly and you appreciate game as art"
date: you will probably love the game. Otherwise you will probably be like me and wish this was a short film instead of a game."

reviewText:
This game is frustrating as hell to play. The controls are so awful on 360 controller, especially the bolas. It's like they had a 3 hour meeting on how to make the absolute worst way to throw an aimed object that you need to be able to quickfire. I think I canceled more bolas than I ever threw them.

The main character is so slow and unresponsive in an environment that requires you to be able to quickly change directions, jump far, and run.

The AI character is OK but likes to get him or herself killed, making you start over. Characters also like to get stuck on walls and glitch out.

The level design is trial-and-error-based platforming. You fall through floors that have no indication that they would break. Other pieces of platforming puzzle are on screen with the current puzzle, making you think that piece is a piece of the current puzzle, wasting your time.

Despite all the game-induced deaths and wasting time with poorly laid out puzzles, I still beat the game in one sitting in 3 hours.

The only price this game is worth is 99 cents.

reviewText:
Full text/Video review here: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-never-alone/

Some games ask the question, “Are video games art?”. Other games definitively answer that question beyond a reasonable doubt. Never Alone is one of the latter. Set in the Alaskan wilderness, this game is based on the tale of Kunuuksaayuka. Made in two and a half years, the developers worked with over 40 Alaskan elders, storytellers, and artists to bring this story to life. Narration is done completely in the Iñupiaq tongue, with subtitles in English, so it’s quite easy to immerse yourself completely. The soundtrack is minimal, but atmospheric. This allows the real barren brutality of the Alaskan wilderness to hit you with full force. Nature can be both friend and foe in this game, and no matter which side you end up on, you can always feel how tiny everything is in the grand scheme of things. Now, this is not a game without it’s flaws, but I think they were able to set a goal and meet it beautifully. With all that said, lets look a little deeper at Never Alone.

The first thing that will probably be noticed in the opening cinematics is the art style used, which based on the Inuit tradition of scrimshaw, and if you didn’t know that, the game quite kindly provides you with something to watch so you can learn about scrimshaw from the actual elders via a cinematic. The cinematics are quite unintrusive, but are still ready for you within seconds when you’re ready to break your immersion via the back button. Little things like this go such a long way for me. The immersion really is something else, as soon as you’ve heard the wind rip apart the background audio a couple times… Or enjoyed the solemn wind tones of an ice cave, you’ll be hooked. It’s not just the graphics or the atmosphere that has me so impressed, the gameplay is actually a ton of fun. As in most puzzle platformers, you will use the different attributes of the characters to traverse the levels. The fox can fit in tinier spaces, walljump, and talk to the animal spirits that sometimes appear to serve as platforms. Nuna can drag heavy objects, and toss a bola. The bola is your only source of damage, and everything kills both characters in one hit… But it’s not taxing. It feels like you’re being told a lovely story the entire time. Some puzzles can take a bit of braining, but the solution always feels so gratifying. Local co-op is amazingly fun, and how I assume the game is supposed to be played, but a fine job was done making sure everything is still doable in single-player.

Aside from the likeable characters, story, and immersive environments, there are the gorgeous graphics in which the environment (and everything else) was rendered. The wind feels alive as it rips at Nuna’s hood, water is rendered wonderfully with beams of light shining through the surface, Nuna’s bola also has it’s own physics, and will land differently every time depending what you hit and how. Again, it really is the little things. Possible faults might include the linear nature of the game, as well as minor bugs involve with jumping on ice you were meant to break with the bola (example on the intro to my video review). The controls could also use some tightening. However, there are a multitude of sincere and fantastic messages, so if you’re in the mood for a story game that leans more toward story, why not also learn about a complex and interesting culture that people don’t talk enough about?

Summary: A casual co-op puzzle-platformer with fantastic immersion.

Final Score: 8/10 for gameplay, graphics, and immersion. 10/10 with difficulty increase.

reviewText:
I really really wanted this game to be good

It's fantastic to see gaming companies working with native people to allow them to tell their stories witht their voices. I was especially impressed that the game could be played entirely in the Iñupiat language. I study anthropology, so this kind of stuff gets me super excited. Plus the game looks gorgeous.

Unfortunately the controls and general glitchiness make playing it a frustrating experience. At first I attributed this to typical Mac gaming ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, but from other reviews it looks like this is a problem with all versions of the game.  The controls are unresponsive, which is unacceptable for a game that relies on quick platforming. The characters  constantly get stuck on walls, fall through the level, or just freeze in midair. This is a very linear game, and I  encountered the glitches over and over in the same spots... spots I needed to get through to progress. It's the kind of thing that should have been caught by playtesters.  If you're still iterested in the game, I'd reccommend watching a let's play instead. That way you get the story and the beautiful imagery minus the frustration.

reviewText:
That little girl has such a shocking reaction whenever her fox dies, I couldn't help but smile.  Her and that litte fox intrigued me.  I *believed* her connection to that fox.  And that is why I decided to purchase.

The story follows an Alaska Native tale.  It feels authentic, at least the narrator makes it so.  The tale is detailed in Alaskan lore without being oversaturated with background information.  Storyline has some nice tension, but doesn't really grab me. At least not in the way I was expecting.  For some reason I was thinking I'd have more game dialogue and exposition.  It's mostly the visuals I enjoy and mini documentaries.  Truthfully, that is the heart of the game.  After some time, I felt less for the characters and just wanted to watch another documentary on Alaskan life.  The magic didn't quite sustain long enough between that fox and Nuna.

Perhaps it was the controls.  A little clunky without co-op, although completely playable.  If you have a friend and a spare controller this game gets a lot better.  Single player wise, it can frustrate you about 2/3rds of the way through.  I would not call it game breaking, though.  Depends how much patience you have as a gamer because several parts are trial and error.  I found the controls had less in common with Tale of Two Brothers than it did with The Cave.  Except The Cave was more entertaining ( mostly ).

So it's a pair of enchanting characters in a beautiful game with what I presume is a  real native tale and tons of awards, yet the game is not amazing.  There is plenty of eyecandy and wonderful documentary bits, yes, but the actual gameplay is so-so.  I'd love to see something more action oriented...I kept thinking with all the nice visuals wouln't some Rayman Legends style platforming be more fitting?  Perhaps it is the two person controls that slow it down.  It's super original and I enjoyed it, but I didn't think the real guts of the game was great.  I'd say 6.5/10 overall.  I may go back and watch the documentaries again, that footage is gorgeous and the people are more enjoyable to watch than the rest of the game.

reviewText:

reviewText:
I've been waiting for this game for the past week and bought at as soon as it was available. I had high hopes for Never Alone and not only were my expectations met, but were even surpassed. From the gorgeous art work and animation to the wonderful story telling in the Iñupiat language, Never Alone will definitly suck you. I did come across a few bugs here and there but never anything game breaking. By the time this review is read, they might even be fixed in a patch.

Pros:

Amazing story with rich narrative
Beautiful art work and animation
Challenging game play for most of the game

Cons:

Can't rebind keys
Multiplayer is hotseat only, meaning you have to be at the same computer rather than across the network or internet
The occasional glitch

Over all, I'd give Never Alone an 8/10

A side note to parents concerned about the ESRB T rating, it really should be rated E 10+ for cartoon violence and difficulty. If this were a tv show or movie it would've been PG not PG-13, at least in my opinion.

reviewText:
IntroductionExperience the epic journey of Nuna and Fox as they search for the source of an eternal blizzard that threatens the survival of everything they have ever known.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=564597459
Tags: Indie, Local Co-Op, Platformer, Adventure, Cute, Atmospheric, Female Protagonist, Local Multiplayer, Casual, Story Rich, Action, Puzzle, Side Scroller, Puzzle-Platformer, Great Soundtrack, Singleplayer, 2D, 2.5D, Short

ProsCharming story based on an Inupiat legend

A cute little arctic fox and Iñupiat girl

Plays very well in local co-op mode.

Achievements are based on progression in the story and finding collectables (owls scattered throughout each stage). Each owl unlocks a short educational video about some element of the Iñupiat culture. If you miss an owl, no worries: once you complete the game you can select which chapter you want to play. (This also goes for Foxtales, which I will explain next).

Foxtales DLC. A must buy in my opinion; it adds another playable story using the same characters as well as adding a new antagonist. It is short, but worth the money if you liked the base game. Foxtales is around 2 hours long.

Seamless transition from singleplayer to co-op. In singleplayer, you can swap between characters to solve puzzles.

Beautiful graphics and soundtrack that go right along with the characters and setting.

Simple puzzles with several boss fights along the way, none of which are too simple or complex. There are lots of checkpoints to make sure you won’t be re-doing significant parts of each level if you die.

Learn about the Inupiat people through a fully narrated story and short interviews. Some may say this game is more of a documentary then a game, and they would be somewhat correct. Puzzle platforming elements are cleverly tied in with historical information.
ConsGlitches. I only ran into a few glitches, none of which were game breaking.

Controls are clunky and sometimes make it hard to navigate.

Gameplay is short: Took me around 6 hours to beat the game and 2 to beat the DLC. This can be overlooked because of the excellent immersion that this game provides for. (If that is why you bought the game)

$15 is a lot to pay for ~6 hours of gameplay. However, if you want to learn about the Iñupiat people and have an immersive experience, then I highly recommend you buy this game.
Highly recommended to buy, if you can overlook the $15 price tag. Although it takes only around 8 hours to complete (including Foxtales DLC), Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is worth a buy for the experience you will have. Has beautiful story, illustrations, and soundtrack, but lacks smooth controls. Never Alone can be enjoyed in singleplayer (ironic, right? Never… alone?...) or co-op mode. This game is one of my top 10 favorites, and I hope it can be one of yours too.

My implemented rating system:Run away! 1-2/10
Handle with caution… 3-4/10
Buy on sale: 5-6/10
Every day purchase: 7-8/10
Must buy: 9-10/10

This game's rating: 8.5/10. Great for regular purchase, a must buy.

reviewText:
Little girl of Iñupiaq people goes out to find a source of a blizzard that is troubling her people and on her way to the answers she is accompanied with a little helper - an arctic fox. Story is of course set in Alaska. I will start off by:
Pros:
- Adorable girl and an adorable little fox make the story all the better, the animation of the tail of the fox is hilarious and cute :')
- Story is exciting, sometimes scary, sad and lovely all at the same time, with one great twist!
- Both the fox and the girl are playable characters that you take control of either in single player or local co-op, as characters. as I said above, they make the story more impactful, but in gameplay terms it fails to deliver (see Cons)
- Art style in-game is very lovely, wind effects are not only cosmetics, they impact the way you play the game
- Cut scene art style differs from the gameplay but is very interesting and is indeed an art style of Iñupiaq people
- Cultural insight videos offer a lot of knowledge about this forgotten community - I knew nothing about them, maybe a little, but now I not only know more - I am impressed by them and their culture!

Now, with the cons:
- Single player puts you in control of both characters, when you control the girl, AI controls the fox, and vice versa. The problem is AI isn't very smart and sometimes levels require quick reaction and cooperation that really requires you play with someone at local coop
- Because these levels require that, you are encountered with frustrating deaths. A lot of them! In fact, the only game I died more at is Limbo. This really made me frustrated.
- The game is short. Most of the time on my Steam clock is thanks to Cultural Insight videos, so 3 hours I think can be enough to complete it.
** I played with Nvidia card on laptop, you must set manually in Nvidia control panel for this game to run on Nvidia card because it automatically sets itself to run on the integrated one and performance will be bad.
All in all, I do recommend this game. I had fun with it, learned a lot, had some frustrating moments, but a wonderful experience none the less. Also, the fox is a must play character in your career (that tail!) ! :)

reviewText: Never alone was a beautiful experience. To those that aren't familiar with multicultures and different societies, it is definitely an eye opener both in terms of education and spiritually speaking. It was also surreal learning the cultural insights of the said tribe and how their perspective and/or religion or way of life is so different than us. We spend most of our time enclosed in our modernized world, too busy and caught up to think of our next meal, our next job, and so playing this game for me was like taking a step back and appreciating the environment and our surroundings for once, if not all the time like them. The gameplay was not that engaging and at times I grew frustrated at the mechanics, but nevertheless it is an experience I wouldn't want anyone to miss. It is also imperative to keep an open mind. No, I was not high while writing this.

reviewText:
I originally posted a review of this game unfinished due to what I thought were progress-breaking glitches and issues with the video viewer the program uses. I was contacted shortly after by a member of the team who assisted in showing me (incredibly politely!) that I forgot a fundamental system of the game and that there were no glitches. I have since finished the game and have watched 23/24 of the documentary videos.

I have changed my review to a recommendation, and will strike out any issues I once had with a write up on what has changed. I will also add some new insights I've found playing through to the end while erasing or touching up parts where I feel my originally negative review has since changed.

----------------------------------------

A fantastic game with an unbelievably charming story, an awesome art style, and a lot to teach. A truly special game that I cannot recommend enough.

Kisima Ingitchuna (what a beautiful name) is a story-based platformer that follows a young girl named Nuna and her fox to discover what has happened to her Alaskan village. A gorgeous canvas for a frustrating platformer that contians an incredible adventure.

Pros:
+ Visually gorgeous, with so much detail using a simple color palette.
+ An interesting, if not simple, story.
+ Narration in the native (Iñupiat) tongue throughout helps to flesh out the world even further.
+ The two player co-op option is a huge plus, and makes the game far more enjoyable.
+ The documentary pieces they have are incredibly well done. Not only do they teach so much about the people and their culture, they also feed back into the game's world through the stories they tell. Every part of nature, every struggle -- every piece that is placed into this game -- comes from the people's stories and their culture. What I would consider to be the highlight of the package.
+ STORY SPOILERS.  The single most tasteful and beautiful animal death in any medium I've encountered, ever. As an animal lover, I've never found animal cruelty/death in a story telling medium to add much positive weight to the lore. The way the death was handled in this game is remarkable in ways I have no desire to spoil further. Massive kudos to the person who thought this one up. :)

Cons:
- I have had progress-breaking bugs twice and am not able to complete the game. After searching online during various sections, I have found myself stuck with no way to progress, even after a hard reset of my system.
Turns out I had forgotten a fundamental system in the game. I have not found any issues like this at all.

- Furthermore, the game comes with many documentary videos on the Alaskan people, which would have been fantastic to watch if they would load at all. Potentially an isolated issue, but one that left me pretty bummed. Will have to venture to YouTube to see them.
Steam can sometimes not install the codec/viewer, and their support team had the issue resolved with a single email. I've added my thoughts on the videos to the Pros section.

- The controls handle incredibly loose. Using a gamepad, I had trouble making consistent jumps, which led to many deaths that felt unfair.

After completing this game and watching the documentary episodes, I cannot be happier with this game. Anyone who enjoys documentaries or thoughtful works will find much to love here. Easily recommended.

reviewText: Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna in the Iñupiaq language) is an indie platformer that transports you into two legends (as of the expansion) from the indigenous Iñupiaq culture of Cook Inlet, Alaska.  You take on the role of two characters: Nuna, a young Iñupiaq girl, and a white fox named... well, Fox (no relation to a certain Nintendo franchise).  In the core game, the pair go on a quest to find the cause of harsh blizzards that are devastating Nuna's community; while in the expansion, Foxtales, they set out to stop the rampage of a giant mouse destroying the countryside.  They might be regarded as weird" storylines from the perspectives of a lot of gamers - but then

reviewText: What a lovely game this is! After struggling a bit booting up (for some reason, graphics only appear when the game is in windowed mode on my system, and I was obliged to update my LAV drivers to see the Cultural Insight Videos, and add the game to my nVidia program settings tab...and the game plays in every resolution BUT my native resolution!), this was a rewarding game that provided not only beautiful art and fun puzzles, but a great deal of insight into the past and present culture and storytelling heritage of the Inupiat people.\n\nI highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys beautifully designed puzzle-platforming games, but especially for those who (like me) also want to support good games featuring stories and heroes not usually given spotlight. My only caveat (besides the flaming hoops to jump through loading it up the first time) is that this game would, I think, have played more smoothly had I the ability to plug in a second controller; there were moments  when I felt the game's design was a little punishing for a solo player hopping back and forth between the two characters. Overall, though, a delightful, insightful package.

reviewText:
Let's pave out the shortcomings before arriving at the scores of strengths this game offers.

Never Alone is a short experience, clocking in at 2-3 hours (played locally on my wife's account), perhaps a bit more. You will have likely read this in the reviews, and I concur that it is a brief game. It could be said that it never outstays its welcome, and that the continuous new challenges introduced with an applaudable learning curve offset its short lifespan, but the fact of its brevity remains nonetheless true.

In addition, we played co-op and found it sometimes difficult to determine exactly where we were going; it was much more of a freeform, faster-paced Limbo experience than, say, a Portal type of deal where the objective is clear from the word Start" in every room. Again
date: what offsets this is the impressive checkpointing that never fails to pick up and keep the pace good and strong throughout.\n\nNow

reviewText:
Tradition and culture play an important role in rural or non-urban regions of human civilization. The Arctic and Antarctic regions are among the coldest places in the world -where survival and community building goes hand in hand. This game is based on the folklore of the Alaskan people - passed down through generations - explaining the harmony of nature with the people and the origination of a blizzard. And if I were to describe it one word - I'd say it was- Beautifully Magical. (I know that's two but I hope you get the point.)

I'm in awe of everything from the unbelievably good level designs - to the traditional style of narration in the native tongue - to the simple idea of having actual real life interviews of people currently living there explaining the background and their way of life. It was a journey that I will cherish right up there with games like To the Moon" and "Limbo".

The soundtracks lend it a surreal feel and completes the whole childrens tale - fantasy like setting. The levels are not too difficult overall
date: but there are a few parts I had to repeat a couple of times. Like I said above
recommended: the game was a magical experience as a whole and hesitating to give it a shot would be travesty of blasphemous proportions."

reviewText:
I'd seen trailers, art, and positive reviews.  So when I got the email that it was on sale this week, I finally picked it up.  After resolving my problem (game getting stuck in co-op mode with only one player), it was a really enjoyable experience.

The music was beautiful and added so much.  The story.  Just wow.  The story was lovely, engaging, and a true pleasure to experience.  And the characters were so very cute and fun, especially spirit-boy Fox.

The gameplay was easy to pick up and challenging, but not to the point of frustration.  Foxtales had a lot more areas that would have been easier with true co-op rather than solo, but you work with what you got.  It just meant more tries and getting eaten a lot.

Good for all ages, provided they have the dexterity to play.  Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Best cultural anthropology I've ever seen in a game; possibly the worst platforming I've ever seen in a game. And since this is Steam, and this is a game, I honestly cannot recommend it. reviewText:
Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a puzzle platform game with a story based on an old folklore from the Iñupiat people of northern Alaska. Nuna starts an adventure with an artic fox companion in order to find the source of the terrible snow storms plaguing her village.
The main core of the game is using your own tool (like the bolas you are given after clearing an early sequence) or the elements of the enviroment (like strong winds, wandering spirits and more) to advance in the levels and avoid dying. Never Alone has actually been envisioned as a co-op game and both characters must survive the various hazards and advance at the same time (else, it's a game over and time to restart from the previous checkpoint). There are also some trial and error elements, but they never get too obnoxious.
While you can actually play the game as a single player, controlling one character at a time and switching when needed, the whole experience is actually a lot harder this way (namely, constantly switching between Nuna and the fox to solve the puzzles becomes tiring aftrer a while and sometimes one of them will die because you weren't there at the right moment to control it/her).
Since the main purpose of the publishers (Upper One Games and E-Line Media) was to get the player now Iñupiat culture and traditions, you can find several owls scatterd around the levels. Reaching them unlocks brief educational movies called cultural insights" for you to check.
The main design of Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is simple yet charming and could as well hook you up for the average three hours of gameplay"
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: There is a lot to like about this game.  Never Alone is artistically beautiful.  Never Alone is educational.  The unlocked cultural videos taught me about the heart and lifestyle of the Inupiat people (something I knew little to nothing about previous to the game).   Never Alone is challenging.  As the game progresses, so does the difficulty.  The only negative to this game I found was the difficulty in playing both characters quickly enough in Single Player towards the end and some occasional bugs with that playstyle.\n\nFinally, Never Alone made me want to hear more folk stories read to me in the native languages of the Inupiat people.  There is something almost musical about their dialect and having the story read to me as I struggled my way through was my favorite part.  Hopefully there will be more DLC in the future :)

reviewText:
This was a hard review to write - it's a hard game not to like, the art style is beautiful and it provides a fascinating insight into an indigienous people/culture that may soon be lost to the world. If you ever want a game you can point at when people claim games can't be art, serve no other purpose than mindless entertainment or violance - this is the game to point them at.

It's a genuinely moving at times, albeit mainly through the video segments that you unlock along the way. The story its self is interesting but for me this game's soul is driven by it's exploration of story telling through games, and opening up access to a culture you would otherwise move through life knowing nothing about.

That said, the game its self is far from flawless. The difficulty curve on the puzzles is random, and the controls at times are clunky. The most frustrating part, to the point that it becomes a distraction, is the companion AI. Some basic puzzles are made more challenging, and some hard puzzles made almost impossible by a random and sporadicly moving AI. The secondary challenge at times being where could you wedge your companion so they can't run off a ledge, or float off so the platform you're stood on dissapears beneath you.

As a medium, and as a piece of engaging storytelling this is pretty expectional and should not be over looked for it does and the message it carries. As a game it is solid, but challenging due to development flaws rather than the core concept. However, do not let that put you off...this is well worth having in your collection and will be 3 hours well spent.

reviewText:
Never Alone is a game whose charm you will desperately want to love, and on the surface there is enough elegance to be intrigued. Unfortunately the Never Alone doesn't do very much as a game. However, as an overall experience, the game still has quite a lot to offer. It is a game I can recommend, just with some caveats, as I do not feel it deserves a thumbs down.

While Never Alone was for the most part somewhat enjoyable, I simply could not shake the feeling of mediocrity that I was left with at the end of the experience. Looking back, this game doesn't bring anything revolutionary to the 2D platforming genre, however, I don't think anybody expected that much. But ultimately, it ends up taking a few steps backwards.

Gameplay and Design:
For the first 90 minutes the platforming felt alright, but about halfway through the fourth chapter things began to fall apart. The true nature of the controls were starting to become more and more apparent. Controlling the characters felt clunkier, attaching to ledges properly sometimes took several tries. The bola stood out as being particularly awkward and could have controlled better to say the least. In a game that seemed to be aiming for simplicity, some of these factors definitely detracted from the experience as a whole.

The level design felt a bit redundant after a while as well, a lot of the levels or particular aspects of them began to feel the same or just too gimmicky, and for a game that can easily be completed in just over three hours this type of design isn't particularly welcome.

Extra Content:
The cultural insights (documentary type clips) were the true star of the show and largely responsible for keeping me interested in the game all the way through. However, first and foremost, the game should be critiqued for how it performs as an actual game. The cultural insights and story are very nice touches but that alone cannot shape the entire experience. In this case however, the cultural insights are the glue that holds everything together.

All in all, Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) has enough charm on its surface to make for a really enjoyable and educational journey. However, a lot of that enjoyment is lost in the boring level design and sometimes mildly frustrating controls that make for a mediocre 2D plaforming experience.

While it is a game I recommend based on its cultural value. If you're looking JUST for a good game think twice before playing.

reviewText:
I probably should have voted this one down.

Yeah, ok, Never Alone is a decent co-op platformer. Not great. Decent. My main problem with this title is that I believe much of the praise given is due to the fact that the game centers its focus on the plight of a minority group. This is Dances with Wolves, the indie version. This is all fine and good - but it does not instantly make a great game on that fact, alone. It still needs to be innovative and be fun to play, right?

Mark my words: if they would have replaced the native Alaskan culture with Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles or Twighlight, the game would have been largely dismissed.

Other than some beautiful graphics (admittadly, alot them look to have significant improvements because of filters), the game is fairly underwhelming. It has all been done before. Seriously.

Pros:
+Stunning graphics and ambience, although there is not much variation. Even in the belly of the 'whale' - its still all ice/glacier graphics.

Meh:
=Controls are ok. Some people complain. We had an ok time with them.
=Co-op puzzles were never difficult at all. We didn't finish the game, but we got close, then we got bored.

Cons:
-Nothing at all fresh with the co-op design.
-A fair amount of repetition and uninspired puzzles (ie. the wind? C'mon its a time waster).
-The story is cookie cutter.

Its fine, but I would not necessarily recommend my Steam friends purchase the game. Watch some LetsPlays and decide for yourself.  I am voting it up, because although I have many issues with the game, it has enough good points to get the vote.

reviewText:
I originally was interested in this game solely because of its graphics. The artwork looked so beautiful, I wanted to see what this game was all about. Once it went on sale, I bought it to give it a try. This game gives you roughly 3 hours of game play, with the option of purchasing a DLC which obviously extends the story. I however did not buy the DLC, so my review will only reflect the actual game.

Never Alone is a story-telling platform that gives you the option of playing in co-op or individually. Not only is this game a piece of art, it gives you insights into another culture you may not have known much about. The game switches between two different art forms in order to tell the story of a young girl and her new found friend. These two friends are inseparable through their journey to protect the girls village. Although this game can be difficult at times, it is an enjoyable puzzle game, that you will use trial and error as well as your problem solving skills to get you through.

I suggest this game to people with all levels of gaming. I especially recommend this game for pairs of friends that have varying levels of gaming, because it allows you to help each other through the puzzles and platforms in many different ways. I myself do not consider myself to have high gaming abilities, but even I was able to help my partner with parts in this game. It has a little bit of something to offer to everyone that plays the game.

One last interesting thing that this game offers that I thought was unique are the cultural insights" built into the game. Similar to the achievements that you will receive while playing through the game
date: you will be awarded these cultural insights. In the main menu
hoursPlayed: you are able to view all of your insights and click on ones you find interesting to watch. These insights will give you more cultural background and extend the games premise if you really enjoyed it. Learning more about the events and stories that helped mold the frameworks of Never Alone is a great bonus for real fans of the game."

reviewText:
Short review, having just completed it (don't worry, no spoilers).

Beautiful game with a story that you'll actually care about, information about Alaskan culture that you'll be interested to soak up and beatiful graphics are all positives.

The game is a little rough around the edges in terms of mechanics, at least when playing solo.  But they are minor irritations when viewing the game as a whole.  I felt a bigger emotional attachment with games like Journey and Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons than this, but I'm not sure that it really warrants the comparison.  This game stands on it's own feet and is still some of the best £/hour entertainment I've had of recent years.

8/10

reviewText:
Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a puzzle platform game with a story based on an old folklore from the Iñupiat people of northern Alaska. Nuna starts an adventure with an artic fox companion in order to find the source of the terrible snow storms plaguing her village.
The main core of the game is using your own tool (like the bolas you are given after clearing an early sequence) or the elements of the enviroment (like strong winds, wandering spirits and more) to advance in the levels and avoid dying. Never Alone has actually been envisioned as a co-op game and both characters must survive the various hazards and advance at the same time (else, it's a game over and time to restart from the previous checkpoint). There are also some trial and error elements, but they never get too obnoxious.
While you can actually play the game as a single player, controlling one character at a time and switching when needed, the whole experience is actually a lot harder this way (namely, constantly switching between Nuna and the fox to solve the puzzles becomes tiring aftrer a while and sometimes one of them will die because you weren't there at the right moment to control it/her).
Since the main purpose of the publishers (Upper One Games and E-Line Media) was to get the player now Iñupiat culture and traditions, you can find several owls scatterd around the levels. Reaching them unlocks brief educational movies called cultural insights" for you to check.
The main design of Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is simple yet charming and could as well hook you up for the average three hours of gameplay"

reviewText: There is a lot to like about this game.  Never Alone is artistically beautiful.  Never Alone is educational.  The unlocked cultural videos taught me about the heart and lifestyle of the Inupiat people (something I knew little to nothing about previous to the game).   Never Alone is challenging.  As the game progresses, so does the difficulty.  The only negative to this game I found was the difficulty in playing both characters quickly enough in Single Player towards the end and some occasional bugs with that playstyle.\n\nFinally, Never Alone made me want to hear more folk stories read to me in the native languages of the Inupiat people.  There is something almost musical about their dialect and having the story read to me as I struggled my way through was my favorite part.  Hopefully there will be more DLC in the future :)

reviewText:
Never Alone tells a story told by the inupiat, the native Alaska people.
And let me tell you it is beatiful. As you play along the game, you unlock sequences, where native people are talking about their lives.
So its actually part game, part documentary.
I played through the game plus the Foxtale DLC in about 4 1/2 hours.

I have to agree the controls are a bit clunky. Is it annoying sometimes? Yes
Is it that annoying that it took away the good experience of a game?      No
Also i got to say i didnt get any glitches in my playthrough.

Overall i got to say this game was fun to play and also a lifelesson learnt.
If you like narrative games with a great story, i can totally recommend you Never Alone

The bola stood out as being particularly awkward and could have controlled better to say the least. In a game that seemed to be aiming for simplicity, some of these factors definitely detracted from the experience as a whole.

The level design felt a bit redundant after a while as well, a lot of the levels or particular aspects of them began to feel the same or just too gimmicky, and for a game that can easily be completed in just over three hours this type of design isn't particularly welcome.

Extra Content:
The cultural insights (documentary type clips) were the true star of the show and largely responsible for keeping me interested in the game all the way through. However, first and foremost, the game should be critiqued for how it performs as an actual game. The cultural insights and story are very nice touches but that alone cannot shape the entire experience. In this case however, the cultural insights are the glue that holds everything together.

All in all, Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) has enough charm on its surface to make for a really enjoyable and educational journey. However, a lot of that enjoyment is lost in the boring level design and sometimes mildly frustrating controls that make for a mediocre 2D plaforming experience.

While it is a game I recommend based on its cultural value. If you're looking JUST for a good game think twice before playing.

reviewText: Never have played a game as unique as this one. As I played along in the visually stunning landscape of this game, I could not help myself but gasp at this or that as I moved the sweet little character along her way. This game offers the player a historic take on the culture, people and folklore. They have cleverly mixed snippets of the legends which surround these remarkable people with amazing survival skills. They have beautiful stories, and they are told and circulate throughout their rich culture down through generations.\nIt is so compelling to manipulate your character through her environment, and I became mesmerised with how she reacts within the terrain. It made me feel like I was with her. The narration gave me chills and actually made me feel very emotional. Maybe that is attributed to a good friend of mine who live north of the Artic in Kotzebue, Alaska, and when I told her about this game she needed to see it. She cried, for it meant a lot, for the stories, and way they depict everything. All I can say is I know I made a great decision to buy this game. I am not nearly done with it, however, after a bit of game play I had to leave this review. I am VERY happy with this game, and am sure it will bring many gaming hours of joy. Go out and buy it! reviewText:
This was definitely an interesting and unique game. It's a cautious recommendation for me, mainly because it's just so damn short! (3-5 hours of content). I got this on Sale for about $10.99 when it first came out and it's hard to say I got my moneys worth. Only reason that It would have been worth the money (for me at least) is because I played it Co-op with my girlfriend. So, that being said, I also have no judgement on how the AI reacts. Co-op, though, definitely does flow well and is pretty damn fun. Especially with the fox imo!

To be honest the 'Local Co-op' was the only real draw to me for this game, because there are so few of games that are worth playing that have this feature on PC! So when this was on sale I grabbed it... and even then I still can't say that it holds its weight in virtual tender. It's just such a short game for the price!


Does this make it a bad game?
Absolutely not, It's a pretty amazing game actually. Definitely visually entertaining

Does it make it worth the price?
Even at half-off it'd be hard to justify spending that much for such a short and easy game...

With all that being said, I still recommend it. I know eventually it'll go on sale 75% or more as far as price is concerned. Also, It's just not a bad game in the least! reviewText:
Beautiful looking game with puzzles on the simpler side, it is more about play for an experience than it is for a challenge, which in reality, make the next couple points even more frustrating.

The bad:
The control setup is rather simple, but it can be really difficult and annoying to get the bola to aim properly or for jumps/character switches/actions to work when you want them to or on the first try. The AI of your partner can also be a bit frustrating at times, they will move when you don't want them to causing them to fall to their death, or move too far away causing a platform to disappear. I would honestly say I died maybe 10 times because of what I would consider my mistake, and about 150 from one of the above problems. Gameplay also gets a bit repetitive as you are doing the same actions over and over (think Assassins Creed 1).

The good:
The story is simple but beautiful, and the graphics and design of the game are gorgeous. The game is rather short, but I would say this is to it's advantage as there is a good chance you will want a second playthrough at some point and the repetitive gameplay puzzles would really burn you out if it was longer than the 2-3 hours it is. The videos included with the game that unlock are pretty heartfelt mini documentaries that I found myself really enjoying. Really glad I unlocked as many as I did (think I missed 2 during the course of play).

All in all a great experience with some frustrations with controls. Would love to see a sequel or another game in the same setting.

reviewText: Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a beautifully done game. Its a very atmospheric puzzle platformer that lets you experience the harsh environment of Alaska. The story is narrated in the native language of the Iñupiat people. Its told about a Iñupiat girl and an arctic fox searching for the source of a blizzard. As you proceed in the game you come across insights. Which are videos that gives you a cultural insight into the beliefs or the lives these people live.\n\nThe controls weren't the best thing in the game, but I was able to over look it. I really watching the little clips that gave me information about the things that happened in the game. Everything had a story behind it. As a game though I would say it probably doesn't have much replay value in it and its relatively short. About 2-3 hours worth of gameplay. The game is local co-op. You can't play with others online. However it would be a great game to experience with someone else. :)

reviewText: This is one of the most wonderful stories I've ever been told. It's a beautiful interactive work of art that transports you to a dangerous icy world while warming up your heart with stunning graphics, ethereal environments, and the loveliest of furry friends. Despite being a very easy platform game, I challenge you not to feel terrible when you accidentally kill one of the characters. As you learn about the Iñupiat culture, you'll quickly morph into Nuna, and for approximately six hours you'll believe that your best friend is the cutest, bravest, most loyal of arctic foxes.\nI give it a 9/10 because the puzzles are far too simple, and the story is, unfortunately, too short.

reviewText:
This game is a side scrolling platformer where you can switch between two characters (a girl and a fox). It's based on a native Alaskan story and is about a girl who sets off to find the source of the blizzards that are harming her village only to find a magic fox who goes along with her

Good points:
-  The animation in this game is beautiful and really adds to the games charm.
- Incoroporates informative videos that you can unlock and watch to learn more about the native Alaskans and their culture.
- Nice story based on native mythology which is relayed by an Alaskan native narrator as you play giving a more authentic atmosphere.
-Fun gameplay that encourages you to use the fox and girls abilities. Also features co-op where one player controls the girl and the other controls the fox.
- Fox Tales DLC is a nice addition that adds a few chapters where another story is told through the medium of the girl and her fox.

Bad points:
- When playing solo the AI character can be a bit unreliable at times as they sometimes fall or miss a jump which put you back to the checkpoint.
- While i really enjoyed it the game is a bit short.

Overall this is a nice charming platformer whose native Alaskan influence give it a unique autentic atmosphere. If you enjoyed Brothers: A tale of two sons you'll enjoy this.

reviewText:
I have been playing this for 80 minutes and it already seems too long. It is quite disappointing, because I was really looking forward to purchasing this game, I had been waiting for a discount which would beat the hardly reasonable price.

Pro:
- original
- relatively nice graphics, atmosphere
- fox
- some puzzles, coordination

Contra:
- the narrator often interferes during attention-demanding scenes, and because he does not speak English, one cannot decide what to pay attention to. The action or the subtitles?
- controls are stubborn, irresponsive, slow
- positioning glitches, script errors hindering the progress
- no real motivation to watch the cultural videos
- no real motivation to go on with this game
- throwing bola is frustrating since it offers no targeting mechanics (except the girl's other arm)

It seems that testing was not given much effort, because there are several obvious points for improvement. Might be a good game, once the the player experience and rewarding is balanced.

Quick resume: Not worth the money, especially while out of sales price.

reviewText:
Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a puzzle platform game with a story based on an old folklore from the Iñupiat people of northern Alaska. Nuna starts an adventure with an artic fox companion in order to find the source of the terrible snow storms plaguing her village.
The main core of the game is using your own tool (like the bolas you are given after clearing an early sequence) or the elements of the enviroment (like strong winds, wandering spirits and more) to advance in the levels and avoid dying. Never Alone has actually been envisioned as a co-op game and both characters must survive the various hazards and advance at the same time (else, it's a game over and time to restart from the previous checkpoint). There are also some trial and error elements, but they never get too obnoxious.
While you can actually play the game as a single player, controlling one character at a time and switching when needed, the whole experience is actually a lot harder this way (namely, constantly switching between Nuna and the fox to solve the puzzles becomes tiring aftrer a while and sometimes one of them will die because you weren't there at the right moment to control it/her).
Since the main purpose of the publishers (Upper One Games and E-Line Media) was to get the player now Iñupiat culture and traditions, you can find several owls scatterd around the levels. Reaching them unlocks brief educational movies called cultural insights" for you to check.
The main design of Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is simple yet charming and could as well hook you up for the average three hours of gameplay"
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: There is a lot to like about this game.  Never Alone is artistically beautiful.  Never Alone is educational.  The unlocked cultural videos taught me about the heart and lifestyle of the Inupiat people (something I knew little to nothing about previous to the game).   Never Alone is challenging.  As the game progresses, so does the difficulty.  The only negative to this game I found was the difficulty in playing both characters quickly enough in Single Player towards the end and some occasional bugs with that playstyle.\n\nFinally, Never Alone made me want to hear more folk stories read to me in the native languages of the Inupiat people.  There is something almost musical about their dialect and having the story read to me as I struggled my way through was my favorite part.  Hopefully there will be more DLC in the future :)

reviewText:
Tradition and culture play an important role in rural or non-urban regions of human civilization. The Arctic and Antarctic regions are among the coldest places in the world -where survival and community building goes hand in hand. This game is based on the folklore of the Alaskan people - passed down through generations - explaining the harmony of nature with the people and the origination of a blizzard. And if I were to describe it one word - I'd say it was- Beautifully Magical. (I know that's two but I hope you get the point.)

I'm in awe of everything from the unbelievably good level designs - to the traditional style of narration in the native tongue - to the simple idea of having actual real life interviews of people currently living there explaining the background and their way of life. It was a journey that I will cherish right up there with games like To the Moon" and "Limbo".

The soundtracks lend it a surreal feel and completes the whole childrens tale - fantasy like setting. The levels are not too difficult overall
date: but there are a few parts I had to repeat a couple of times. Like I said above

reviewText:
I'd seen trailers, art, and positive reviews.  So when I got the email that it was on sale this week, I finally picked it up.  After resolving my problem (game getting stuck in co-op mode with only one player), it was a really enjoyable experience.

The music was beautiful and added so much.  The story.  Just wow.  The story was lovely, engaging, and a true pleasure to experience.  And the characters were so very cute and fun, especially spirit-boy Fox.

The gameplay was easy to pick up and challenging, but not to the point of frustration.  Foxtales had a lot more areas that would have been easier with true co-op rather than solo, but you work with what you got.  It just meant more tries and getting eaten a lot.

Good for all ages, provided they have the dexterity to play.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: Never alone was a beautiful experience. To those that aren't familiar with multicultures and different societies, it is definitely an eye opener both in terms of education and spiritually speaking. It was also surreal learning the cultural insights of the said tribe and how their perspective and/or religion or way of life is so different than us. We spend most of our time enclosed in our modernized world, too busy and caught up to think of our next meal, our next job, and so playing this game for me was like taking a step back and appreciating the environment and our surroundings for once, if not all the time like them. The gameplay was not that engaging and at times I grew frustrated at the mechanics, but nevertheless it is an experience I wouldn't want anyone to miss. It is also imperative to keep an open mind. No, I was not high while writing this.

reviewText:
I originally posted a review of this game unfinished due to what I thought were progress-breaking glitches and issues with the video viewer the program uses. I was contacted shortly after by a member of the team who assisted in showing me (incredibly politely!) that I forgot a fundamental system of the game and that there were no glitches. I have since finished the game and have watched 23/24 of the documentary videos.

I have changed my review to a recommendation, and will strike out any issues I once had with a write up on what has changed. I will also add some new insights I've found playing through to the end while erasing or touching up parts where I feel my originally negative review has since changed.

----------------------------------------

A fantastic game with an unbelievably charming story, an awesome art style, and a lot to teach. A truly special game that I cannot recommend enough.

Kisima Ingitchuna (what a beautiful name) is a story-based platformer that follows a young girl named Nuna and her fox to discover what has happened to her Alaskan village. A gorgeous canvas for a frustrating platformer that contians an incredible adventure.

Pros:
+ Visually gorgeous, with so much detail using a simple color palette.
+ An interesting, if not simple, story.
+ Narration in the native (Iñupiat) tongue throughout helps to flesh out the world even further.
+ The two player co-op option is a huge plus, and makes the game far more enjoyable.
+ The documentary pieces they have are incredibly well done. Not only do they teach so much about the people and their culture, they also feed back into the game's world through the stories they tell. Every part of nature, every struggle -- every piece that is placed into this game -- comes from the people's stories and their culture. What I would consider to be the highlight of the package.
+ STORY SPOILERS.  The single most tasteful and beautiful animal death in any medium I've encountered, ever. As an animal lover, I've never found animal cruelty/death in a story telling medium to add much positive weight to the lore. The way the death was handled in this game is remarkable in ways I have no desire to spoil further. Massive kudos to the person who thought this one up. :)

Cons:
- I have had progress-breaking bugs twice and am not able to complete the game. After searching online during various sections, I have found myself stuck with no way to progress, even after a hard reset of my system.
Turns out I had forgotten a fundamental system in the game. I have not found any issues like this at all.

- Furthermore, the game comes with many documentary videos on the Alaskan people, which would have been fantastic to watch if they would load at all. Potentially an isolated issue, but one that left me pretty bummed. Will have to venture to YouTube to see them.
Steam can sometimes not install the codec/viewer, and their support team had the issue resolved with a single email. I've added my thoughts on the videos to the Pros section.

- The controls handle incredibly loose. Using a gamepad, I had trouble making consistent jumps, which led to many deaths that felt unfair.

After completing this game and watching the documentary episodes, I cannot be happier with this game. Anyone who enjoys documentaries or thoughtful works will find much to love here. Easily recommended.

reviewText: What a lovely game this is! After struggling a bit booting up (for some reason, graphics only appear when the game is in windowed mode on my system, and I was obliged to update my LAV drivers to see the Cultural Insight Videos, and add the game to my nVidia program settings tab...and the game plays in every resolution BUT my native resolution!), this was a rewarding game that provided not only beautiful art and fun puzzles, but a great deal of insight into the past and present culture and storytelling heritage of the Inupiat people.\n\nI highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys beautifully designed puzzle-platforming games, but especially for those who (like me) also want to support good games featuring stories and heroes not usually given spotlight. My only caveat (besides the flaming hoops to jump through loading it up the first time) is that this game would, I think, have played more smoothly had I the ability to plug in a second controller; there were moments  when I felt the game's design was a little punishing for a solo player hopping back and forth between the two characters. Overall, though, a delightful, insightful package.

reviewText: The concept of this game was so profound, but the execution was extremely poor.  Graphics and playability were on point, but the game itself was very buggy.  As a QA Manager myself, I would have never allowed this game to go to Production.  Several times I had to hard reset the game as a character would get stuck or the level would simply not load.  I'm running a very serious rig and there should never be an issue to execute the most basic of scene transitions.  The game itself felt rushed and I'm sure there was an over-ambitious deadline for the Dev team to attempt to reach market readiness.  Would have loved to see a fully realized concept that not only respected the generational tradition of historical storytelling among the native North American tribes, but also a fun and engaging platformer with more freedom and non-linear decision making.  It took me a total of 3 hours to complete the main and DLC game - would not recommend if you are looking for replayabilty, but if you find it on special - might be distracting for a little while.
