reviewText:
Beautiful and cute. For me, the attraction of this game comes from the incredible atmosphere, the graphics are simplistic but look great nonetheless, while the animations are absolutely perfect. Practically every scene is believable and the story drives you on.

The documentary clips are optional which I really appreciate. They are very interesting and definitely worth watching, but would destroy the atmosphere were they played automatically.

Gameplay-wise, this is a basic two-character platformer where both characters are required to solve the puzzles presented to you. Most of the time, the puzzles are quite simple, though sometimes you are distracted by surplus platforms or an unfortunate view prevents you from seeing the solution. Later in the game, the single-player difficulty rises significantly, as rapid switching and accurate control of the characters is required due to timers in the scene. It's quite short however, I played it through in less than four hours and I'm really bad playing platformers.

Use a controller, this game won't be fun with a keyboard.

reviewText:
Never Alone is a gorgeous game. It looks great, sounds great, and was an utter joy to play. Never in my life have I played a game, or even been interested in a game, that was meant to actually teach you something. But, this game does just that. The narrative comes straight from stories told by the Iñupiat people. At first glance, it's just an interesting legend-like story that could've very well originated from just this game, but when you realize this is from and about an actual culture, it becomes even more captivating. In addition, you can unlock mini-documentary minute or two long videos throughout the game that explain even more about the culture and the parts of the story. They are very well done, and are short, and so easy to watch (I actually began to wish there was more!).

Now, as far as gameplay goes, the game is an atmospheric platformer. I played entirely in single player and finished the game in one sitting in about 3 hours. They nail the atmosphere perfectly, and the world is a joy to look at. It feels alive. As far as gameplay goes, though, it doesn't stray too far from standard platformers. The girl can jump, move around blocks, and use a throwing weapon to break ice. The fox can wall jump, run up walls, and interact with spirits (which act like moving platforms) that appear throughout the game. Later in the game, the fox's spirit abilities become much more in-depth, too. Personally, I found this to work very well. While not being the most unique gameplay, it was fun and the level design difficulty was scaled well. The later levels can give you quite a bit of challenge (in single player especially), too.

However, I did run into a couple glitches while playing. There was a moving platform section of the game where the platforms would squish you if you weren't quick. However, when jumping from one to the next at one point, you would sometimes just go through the platform. This glitch was compounded with the fact that the AI would lag behind your movement and often fall into the platform when you hadn't, forcing you to redo it. There were a couple other small collision glitches like that, but they weren't nearly as bad. Thankfully, the game is very generous with it's spawn points, and I never had to redo much when I died in the game (which was admittedly often). In addition to glitches, there were a couple places where the AI would do things that were frustrating. Thankfully, I only ran into AI issues a few times, and since you can take control of the AI if need be, it only caused me frustration once or twice, when it actually resulted in a death.

Overall, I'd recommend this game to everyone who enjoys video games. It's charming, tells a very real story while making it actually interesting, and, most importantly, it's very fun. It is a bit highly priced for the length, but I'd say it's worth supporting so we see more games like this in the future. This game is a fantastic experience.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I cannot recommend this game highly enough.  It is one of the rare experiences where I wished it would never end, and found myself not wanting to play the last chapter just to be able to maintain that illusion for myself.  Absoluetly beautiful visuals (especially the wonderful yet terrifying northern lights), enthralling story narrated in Iñupiat, and interesting side-scroller puzzles.  The cultural videos unlocked through play give the story a grounding I have never seen before.  This game, and especially the video interviews with the elders and cultural embassadors, is one of the few games to make me feel like I've changed as a person.  Truly a wonderful experience, and one I can say in all honesty I will carry with me for my lifetime.  Quyanaq.

reviewText: This is unreal.  Forget about controls and those that whined about it. .they are fine and came quite natural to me once I got the hang of it.  That said, I feel like I have been sitting in front of a native there with the honor of being passed something so sacred with all it's wisdom.  If you are just into a gaming experience with like bang bang they are dead, don't get it.  I hope with all my heart they make more.  Maybe just a few get it" but not everyone is ready for it. The art is just amazing.  I've worked in gaming development and I know what it is like to get something like this out.  My hope of a career in with something this meaningful is gone
date:
but I I can sure shout kudos to those that can... and this deserves all sorts of awards.

Create an awesome day!

~ ish"

reviewText:
Playing Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) felt to me like stepping into a folk tale: not just reading it, but actually experiencing and overcoming the obstacles that the heroes face in that story. It's an actual folk tale, not just one made up for the game. Even better, it comes with deep context. I wasn't just avoiding green ghosts while platforming, I was hiding from the Northern Lights and the ghost children that wanted to play football with my head.

This game is probably most enjoyable for in-between gamers. Hardcore players might get frustrated that the characters won't turn on a dime, and very casual players will likely find the last few chapters frustratingly hard. If you're in the middle, and enjoy story, learning about culture, atmosphere, and animation detail, Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a great experience. Personally, I think it's worth playing even you you never make it through to the end.

Second to playing the beautiful white fox, I found the cultural insights" to be one of my favorite features of the game. I love collecting things in a game
date: and trying to find every single owl was a great reason to explore the game's settings thoroughly. Some of the insight videos were like mini documentaries
recommended: telling me things about how this native culture exists in the modern day. Many of the videos were stories: life and death experiences that had happened to the tellers or their family. Almost all provided depth and background to the game: I learned the traditions of the Northern Lights
hoursPlayed: I really felt the abandoned landscape of King Island
voteText: I saw how the art of the cut scenes came from on the style of real-world scrimshaw
helpfulPercent: and I got to hear several other traditional stories. I strongly suggest not waiting until the end of the game to watch the insights you unlock."

reviewText:
Very nice game, I'd say it's probably for the milder puzzle fans. There's a part where you need to do some stuff in a panic, but it counts for like 5% of the game. I like that, but I can leave other's to their own opinions.

It's a very educational game, no doubt. By this, I mean to say that it's agenda is to teach you about the real life of the natives of Alaska through videos. In game you solve puzzles; the game's story line is 100% off folklore of the Alaskans.

I do have a problem regarding the educational video pop-ups, however. You go tend to get them a lot and while you can just ignore them, they're rather hard to do so at first. I almost always have a nagging feeling to press whatever button the screen tells me when I first play, but after some time this goes away and you just know when an educational video notification will occur. Another problem is when the scene cuts and you're moving to a new area, you actually have to say no to a video to progress. It won't start or anything, it just gives you the option to watch one right then and there or not. It's a little weird.

I didn't think the controls were clunky, but there were a couple times when the AI controlling you're other half (you're either little girl or fox; you can switch) will suicide off a cliff and it's really annoying. Usually, though, the AI does a fine job of keeping up with you and you can usually predict what they'll do.

For whatever reason I had low frame rates and tried tinkering with it (I mean, it ran fine) the game just seems to require a lot of GPU for whatever reason.

reviewText: A interesting story Driven narrative about a girl and a wild fox whom travel through alaska facing many dangers. From what I've played so far the game is interestingly challenging especially in the later sections as you swap from the girl to the fox to solve multiple puzzles. The game can be very frustrating sometimes as you have to repeat several sections over and over again do to dieing alot. But the story is beutifull and the soundtrack is also. Also, the sound quality of the game and the voice acting of the narrarater is great! I found myself sunk into the story as I continued forth with my pet fox. Did I mention I love foxes?" The game is far from perfect as I experienced some bugs here and there with terrain and some clipping issues but that didn't destroy the experience for me. Over all rating I'd give it a 10/10 because of the amount of detail there was in the foreground and background. And the history/ culture that you uncover through discovery."

reviewText:
This is a beautiful game. I enjoy it a lot. The art style does really fit and the plot is really interesting.
I highly recomend it to people who like a cultural background, while enjoying a game that's easy to play.
So I think casual gamers won't have a problem here. At the beginning it might be easy to play, because it's mostly a simple sidescroller (running from left to right) and the game teaches you the mechanics. But the more you progress, the game is getting more and more difficult and you have to solve puzzles. Also the game does not simply revolve around running from the left side of the screen to the right, after a certain levell. Meaning the puzzles are getting more and more difficult too.

If you like a culture based story, narrated by a really comforting voice and you like to solve puzzles. Then this is the game for you!

reviewText:
A cute and atmospheric little puzzle platformer clearly designed with co-operative play in mind. Based off of an old Inupiat legend, this game is a great way to educate outsiders on an old fairy tale. There really needs to be more video games with this kind of style, allowing you to learn something new while playing.

Surprisingly short, which is disappointing since the game is a joy to watch and listen to. There are some very frustrating parts of the game that tipped uncomfortably in the negative direction of the fairness scale, mainly due to some scripted events and imprecise controls.

Not a 10/10 like everyone's claiming, but a solid 8/10. Without the intriguing Inupiat storyline this game wouldn't be notable at all, as many other games have come along and done platformers much better.

reviewText: This game is short but its good, you can beat it in one sitting. Its a simple platform and solving type game.  You have a fox that helps you reach areas a person can't and you can switch over back and forth.   There are some spiritual forms and elements like wind that may help or can cause trouble to reach your goal.  The game also has these mini documentry vidoes about the Iñupiat people and about Arctic life. Its rewarding to earn the videos as you play on.  The game is about One of the many stories of the Iñupiat.  This has Local Coop play as one more person can play as the fox and help you play the game if you wanted to.  Played perfectly fine with a gamepad.\n\nI really enjoyed this game. I hope this inspires other developers to make games that tell a cultural tale.  For example, like an Native American tale or something from south america like Incan or Aztec sort of tale.  Well worth getting this game when on sale since its a short game play. Or if you want to support the developers pay the retail price. I Would recommend this game to friends

reviewText:
Play Co-Op.

One player suffers from moderate clipping, suicidal AI partner, player-killing partner, and chase scene delays.  Also, the game offers no key mapping, so some controls may be awkward.  I recommend using the keyboard/mouse for the human character.

Otherwise, I love the idea of the game and the videos that go along with it.  The gameplay and cultural elements have a lot of room to expand, so I hope I get to see another game like this in the future.

reviewText:
Maannakiaq! Aliasuŋitpkaqtil̵l̵utuaŋa qaqasauraquraaqtuq. Iḷitkiga Inuit iñuggusiql̵auraq. Kiikavsaaq! Perfect! I had fun while playing the computer. I learned a little about the Inuit way of life. I want more!

In fact, I would love if the game had more information on the language (or at least have a transcription of the story written out in Iñupiaq) - but I'm a languague geek, so maybe that's just me.

This was a fantastic game to play.  In the past, I spent time in Alaska where I gained an interest in the Inuit language and culture. Seeing the videos with insight into the Inuit culture, along with following a story completely narrated in the Inuit language. The gameplay itself was also pretty fun. I enjoyed the fact that you had to use teamwork to accomplish anything, although it did get a bit annoying to switch between Nuna and Fox sometimes (especially when the non-controlled started doing things that hampered my progress). I really loved the setting of the arctic, as well as unlocking the videos as I made my way through the story.

The only real issues I had: throwing/aiming the bola was a pain, and a weird situation I where I'd control both characters at once with my controller. That proved to be an easy fix by saving a few lines as autoexec.cfg (fix is listed on the game's website).

reviewText: You need to have patience to play Never Alone. A lot of patience. It's a platformer, but the focus is on the Inupiat culture and not the actual gameplay. The Fox is wonderfully animated and his AI is pretty good (and the sounds he makes are absolutely ADORABLE). The same can't be said for the little girl. Her AI sucks. Example: I'll be playing as Fox to do something, and she'll just kind of walk off a ledge while I'm trying to make a nature spirit approach her. It'd probably be a lot easier co-op, but you'll probably end up fighting over who gets to be Fox because he's more fun and more forgiving.\nI wouldn't recommend this to anyone who's not interested in different cultures, because the gameplay's not all that tight. Sometimes, the game expects you to die (who expects a walkway to snap suddenly and throw you over a chasm?) and there's really no skill involved there, just knowing what's ahead. The story is a very old folk tale passed down generationally, and the game features lots of video clips of the Inupiat elders (skippable). Very pretty and artistic, but not worth the price, unless you're a culture buff. Recommended only on sale. 6/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: The art is beautiful, the gameplay is simple yet interesting, and the cultural insight videos you can find along the way are really interesting. It's not very long, I think I finished it in 3 hours or so, but its still nicely done. The animations are very well done too, with a lot of eye for detail, like your hood blowing in the wind :) I played it single player, but I reckon it will be a lot of fun with a second person on a controller controlling the little fox sidekick. If you're interested in playing atmospheric little platformer that plays out an old Iñupiaq tale, and teaches you a bit about these remarkable people living in very harsh environments, I can definitly recommend picking this game up.

reviewText:
Very nice game, I'd say it's probably for the milder puzzle fans. There's a part where you need to do some stuff in a panic, but it counts for like 5% of the game. I like that, but I can leave other's to their own opinions.

It's a very educational game, no doubt. By this, I mean to say that it's agenda is to teach you about the real life of the natives of Alaska through videos. In game you solve puzzles; the game's story line is 100% off folklore of the Alaskans.

I do have a problem regarding the educational video pop-ups, however. You go tend to get them a lot and while you can just ignore them, they're rather hard to do so at first. I almost always have a nagging feeling to press whatever button the screen tells me when I first play, but after some time this goes away and you just know when an educational video notification will occur. Another problem is when the scene cuts and you're moving to a new area, you actually have to say no to a video to progress. It won't start or anything, it just gives you the option to watch one right then and there or not. It's a little weird.

I didn't think the controls were clunky, but there were a couple times when the AI controlling you're other half (you're either little girl or fox; you can switch) will suicide off a cliff and it's really annoying. Usually, though, the AI does a fine job of keeping up with you and you can usually predict what they'll do.

For whatever reason I had low frame rates and tried tinkering with it (I mean, it ran fine) the game just seems to require a lot of GPU for whatever reason.

reviewText:
A cute and atmospheric little puzzle platformer clearly designed with co-operative play in mind. Based off of an old Inupiat legend, this game is a great way to educate outsiders on an old fairy tale. There really needs to be more video games with this kind of style, allowing you to learn something new while playing.

Surprisingly short, which is disappointing since the game is a joy to watch and listen to. There are some very frustrating parts of the game that tipped uncomfortably in the negative direction of the fairness scale, mainly due to some scripted events and imprecise controls.

Not a 10/10 like everyone's claiming, but a solid 8/10. Without the intriguing Inupiat storyline this game wouldn't be notable at all, as many other games have come along and done platformers much better.

reviewText: I loved this game. It might be considered short but I think it's length is perfect for the story it's telling. I highly recommend this if you want something cute and fun for a Sunday afternoon.

reviewText:
Never Alone is a gorgeous and atmospheric story that follows the adventures of Nuna and her fox. The gameplay and the puzzles involved are engaging and although the game is a little on the short side, it is still fun to play.

If you're a lover of art like myself, you will really appreciate this game. The artworks are stunning and the character designs really draw you into the world of the Iñupiat people. The cultural, insights that you can unlock through playing the game, delve deep into the world of Native Alaskan lore, which actually makes you want to learn more about the culture and the people.

Overall I really enjoyed this game and would recommend it to anyone who is into this genre or style of game. Definitely a good buy if you can catch it on sale.

reviewText:
Never Alone is an interesting approach to the puzzle-platformer with some innovative techniques in two-character gameplay.
It suffers from being poorly optimized however, which pulls the gamer out of the experience at times.

I did enjoy learning about the Eskimo culture however, I would like more games with accurate histories that were actually fun to play like Never Alone.

reviewText: A promising concept that unfortunately doesn't achieve much beyond that. Never Alone is a game of frustrating trial and error backed by clunky controls, overshadowing its intriguing folklore. I appreciate the effort in bringing a culture to life through a video game, however I don't believe it deserves a free pass just because of that.\n\nWould only recommend picking up at a discounted price.

reviewText: Where to start... This game is in my personal indie game of the year list.  I very much enjoyed this game.  This is a side-scroller game with simple controls.  The background of the game is that you play as an native Alaskan Inuit girl who is on a quest to try to save her village from an evil spirit man.  Along her journey she befriends a fox who you the player, can switch between to help along the journey.  The graphics are very nicely done as well.  Another aspect of the game that I personally really enjoyed was the short video clips explaining real life experiances and daily life of the Inuit people narrated by them.  There are minor movement bugs but this does not take away from the game experiance at all.  Overall I had a great time playing this game and learning the culture of the Inuit people, I would recommend this game to anyone.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Never Alone, ah.. This game caught my interest, only a short time before it came out. And I do not regret getting it. It was a great experience, so yes, I do recommend it. However, it still has a couple of flaws, that I would like to shortly highlight.

Pros:
The story, oh, the story. This, I feel, is truly the shining strength of this game. In it, we follow Nuna and her friend, the fox. It's a Iñupiat tale, widespread over the entire Arctic, made into a beautiful game. The story draws you in and truly captures your heart.
The music is absolutely wonderful. It's subtle enough not to get in the way at any point, yet it still draws you into the story. It's wonderfully crafted, and I found myself every now and then just stopping up to listen.
Aesthetically, this game overwhelmed me. It's so incredibly beautiful. The art of the actual game is lovely animated and visually pleasing, whilst the cut-scenes appear like the Iñupiat bone carvings. A joy to look at!
Co-Op. I cannot stress this enough - Team up with a dear friend of yours with a passion for learning new cultures, and you will have a -blast-.
The cultural insight surprised me at first, but it's incredibly educating and very fun to listen, as you're told about the Iñupiat culture, other than just this legend.
This game has been very lovingly created, and it shows. Throughout the entirety of it, you can sense the developer's joy in sharing their stories. It translates into a very enjoyable experience.
Whilst it's mostly a story/adventure game, I would like to point out that it often have very challenging puzzles. Now, while I realise that this can be a con for some, it made it more enjoyable for myself. There were times I had to truly sit back and think about how to proceed, as they often utilises the mechanics in the game in refreshing ways.
The cultural insights in this game are unlocked by various owls hidden" in the world. Although

reviewText:
It's a work of art and a cultural embassy, and excellent as both of those.

I found the gameplay itself enjoyable: it's a simple but elegant platformer, sweet and to the point.
The environment and characters are stunningly beautiful.
The narrative is archetypal, reinforcing the cultural insights the game is designed around.

The two main characters are *adorable*. I'm not often moved by that but you would need a heart of stone not to awwww" at the fox.

If you prize long gameplay

recommended: it is not difficult as platformers go

voteText: artistry and/or cultural learning -- you will enjoy and almost certainly cherish this game.\n\nAlso

reviewText:
It's an intersting experience, and a neat look into a different culture.

BUT: The gameplay is bad. Really bad. In the beginning it's just kinda boring, bust that's ok because the rest of the game is good and it's more of a vehicle for the story and world.

However, the later parts get a good bit harder, and it gets frustrating. The controls are unresponsive, the bola control is just awful, hitboxes can be wierd and platforms despawn if the fox drifts of too far.

It's also slow, so when you die through no fault of your own, you get to sit through a slow death animation and get to slowly plod back to where you were. It's never that far, but it happens so often that it becomes a chore to play anyway. It gets even worse after the fox spirit thing.

Finally, the game can't even keep its own rules. Sometimes water kills, sometimes she can dive forever. Sometimes falling kills, sometimes it does nothing. Sometimes wild snow means wind, sometimes it doesn't.

I can't really recommend playing it. If you like the idea, watch an LP of it and you'll have a much better experience.

reviewText:
For a game as visually beautiful and full of atmosphere as this is, the game itself, well.. kinda sucks. The visuals, as mentioned before are stellar. I am not exaggerating when I say that this game is gorgeous. The sound, likewise, is amazing. This game really could be described as a work of art.

Now if the game wasn't so full of bugs and bad play mechanics, it might actually be a joy to play. Right about the point where you start to get into the meat of the game, it becomes an exercise in frustration. From bugs that prevent moving forward because of bad wall/ledge detection, to a stupendously BAD aiming/shooting mechanic for the bolo, this game sets you in places where it's almost impossible to progress. A shame because everything else about the game, from the wonderful cultural videos, to the amazing stylistic storytelling, to the aforementioned beautiful visuals, is PERFECT.

But the game is so fricking frustrating I simply cannot recommend it for purchase.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: The idea behind this game is something I can really get behind, I feel more games should engage the gaming community and teach them something about the world or in this case another culture. This being said, platforming games should be built from the ground up starting with their platforming mechanics. Without smooth platforming mechanics a platformer becomes at the very least frustrating, boring, or unrewarding and at the very worst unplayable. It is very clear that this game was made as a vehicle to teach people about a culture through adapted folklore and as a result the platforming mechanics have taken a backseat to storytelling. The platforming mechanics can get clunky and cumbersome at times and swimming portions can become down right irritating. However, overall I was won over by the concept behind, art direction and storytelling of this game.

reviewText: Never Alone is based on the Inupiat legend of Kunuuksaayuka. The visuals and storytelling are beautiful. The attempts it makes to educated the gamer on Inupiat culture is admirable and ultimately well done. The game play could be a little glitchy but I found it worked far better when I turned the resolution down slightly, it still looked stunningly beautiful and the mechanics worked far better. I played solo and did run into problems when Nuna would be on a spirit and fox would move too far away causing the spirit to disappear and Nuna to fall to her death, which was incredibly frustrating but would be fixed playing with a friend. Also I found that when I turned off the game when I came back it would go back to the beginning of the level rather than to the last checkpoint, starting back up at the last checkpoint would have been far preferable. Still a beautiful game and there were at least a few achievments and easter eggs that I didn't get the first playthrough, giving it some replayability.

reviewText: What a breath of fresh air this game was. A true pleasure to play. Not too difficult, not too easy. It moves at steady pace. I played a little of it every other day and throughly enjoyed the whole thing! I'd suggest anyone looking for a kind of relaxing platformer with and interesting story pick this right up! voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game reminded me a lot of Journey, except with greater emphasis on the story and interaction between two main characters. The game starts off as a fairly simple platformer, running, jumping and avoiding gusts of wind, but as the story progresses you get more actions for both characters adding very interesting movement puzzles. I played this single player and to that end it's limited as the AI can get troublesome in addition to have to switch characters rapidly between timed events. I would highly recommend playing this with someone else as that is where the game shines. Figuring out the puzzles together and working with different abilities is very fun and rewarding.

The story is also very engrossing like an old fairy tale. You also get glimpses into the native Alaskan lifestyle both past and present with Cultural Insights" which are unlocked minute or so segments which tell you about their history and culture. These usually have to do with part of the game you unlock them in and I found interesting and not distracting from the game itself.

Graphics and sound are both spot on. The art syle looks amazing and creates some very beautiful landscapes. Equally the sound effects and music help bring you to that cold wintery land feeling."

reviewText: I must saw, the story of this game is great. Culturally enriching in a way that few other games are.\n\nThe gameplay, however, is absolutely horrid. The game attempts to hold your hand every step of the way. Unfortunately, when the hand lets go the game is brutally punishing. The camera pans in the wrong direction making it extraordinarily hard to complete a simple objective, and the 'last boss' fight is needlessly difficult. Everything seems to function at a snail's pace, leaving very little up to skill. Not recommended.

reviewText: Never Alone is a beautiful heartfelt story of a young girl determined to find the reason for a blizzard engulfing her village. The narrative is told through several different methods. Traditional native art and animation, an amazing co-op and single player platformer, and Iñupiat documentaries. The films are used as extras and not only make the tale more authentic, but they add some cultural education to the experience. The Narrator speaks in Iñupiat and then it is translated into english subtitles keeping the true dialect in tact. I finished this game with my 8 year old daughter and really enjoyed it through the whole experience. I highly recommend this game, especially if you have someone to play it with.

reviewText:
Really enjoyed this game.  The concept of telling a folk-story interspersed with non-intrusive documentary footage (cultural insights) through a video game works brilliantly.  It should be a touchstone for a new style of storytelling within the medium of games.

Other reviews have issues with the controls, but I didn't find them that distracting or worse than other platformers.  It didn't take away from my game experience.  There were a couple instances where the polar bear didn't trigger the puzzle solution, and it took a few restarts to get it going, but these were minor issues.

It is a short game (under 4 hrs with videos), but I think well worth it.  Pick it up at the next Steam sale if you're hesitant on the time/cost value.

reviewText:
I had really high hopes for this game after seeing previews.. Sadly though it became a let down.

The controls were clunky and difficult at times.

The AI  caused death quite a bit.

Theres is no replayability.

The cultural insights were sometimes interesting however I found them to be very boring.. The majority of the time lacking any real info other than someone telling a little story or how they felt.

The story was interesting to a degree but the length of the game made it a let down in the end. 4.6 hours to do everything (would'av been quicker if I didn't doze off)

The characters and art surrounding the levels were the only saving grace imo and they even destroyed that towards the end.

For this I can't bring myself to recommend this game and imo is not worth buying even at the sale price currently at 40% off (4th March 2015)

reviewText:
Never Alone, ah.. This game caught my interest, only a short time before it came out. And I do not regret getting it. It was a great experience, so yes, I do recommend it. However, it still has a couple of flaws, that I would like to shortly highlight.

Pros:
The story, oh, the story. This, I feel, is truly the shining strength of this game. In it, we follow Nuna and her friend, the fox. It's a Iñupiat tale, widespread over the entire Arctic, made into a beautiful game. The story draws you in and truly captures your heart.
The music is absolutely wonderful. It's subtle enough not to get in the way at any point, yet it still draws you into the story. It's wonderfully crafted, and I found myself every now and then just stopping up to listen.
Aesthetically, this game overwhelmed me. It's so incredibly beautiful. The art of the actual game is lovely animated and visually pleasing, whilst the cut-scenes appear like the Iñupiat bone carvings. A joy to look at!
Co-Op. I cannot stress this enough - Team up with a dear friend of yours with a passion for learning new cultures, and you will have a -blast-.
The cultural insight surprised me at first, but it's incredibly educating and very fun to listen, as you're told about the Iñupiat culture, other than just this legend.
This game has been very lovingly created, and it shows. Throughout the entirety of it, you can sense the developer's joy in sharing their stories. It translates into a very enjoyable experience.
Whilst it's mostly a story/adventure game, I would like to point out that it often have very challenging puzzles. Now, while I realise that this can be a con for some, it made it more enjoyable for myself. There were times I had to truly sit back and think about how to proceed, as they often utilises the mechanics in the game in refreshing ways.
The cultural insights in this game are unlocked by various owls hidden" in the world. Although

reviewText: Never Alone is a remarkable game, not because of the actual gameplay but because of its cultural significance. It tells a traditional Inupiat (an Alaska Native people) story and the narrator actually tells the story in Inupiat, which really helps to ground the game in the traditional culture. In between stages, you unlock short documentary videos about different aspects of Inupiat life and culture. The game itself is a fairly standard puzzle platformer. It has some interesting ideas and mechanics, but it also has some jankiness and some annoying trial-and-error gameplay. Overall, though, the gameplay is fun and checkpoints are plentiful, so even if you hit a rough spot you're back in the game immediately. But it's really the cultural aspects that infuse the gameplay with so much more depth than the mechanics could on their own. It might be just another decent platformer, but it's an exceptional game.

reviewText:
Never alone


Never alone is an Indie 2D platformer adventure game that features local Co-Op and a unique storyline developed with the Native Alaskan community that tells the story of a young Iñupiat girl and her Arctic Fox champion. Never alone takes you to the harsh landscapes of Alaska where you will encounter various dangers and helpful spirits. The game also incorporates documentaries about the Iñupiat people and their culture through the game in between levels which adds a nice touch to the law behind the game.

Never alone is a beautiful game centred around the relationship of the two playable characters Nuna the young Iñupiat girl and an Arctic Fox. You will find yourself solving problems and puzzles that requires the use of both characters skills in a way that Limbo fans would find enjoyable. The player will find themselves running away from Polar Bears, battling winds and jumping from collapsing ice blocks. Both characters have unique abilities that will need to be utilised to overcome obstacles and puzzles. The Fox is able to scale walls and summon spirits for Nuna and itself to get over obstacles. Nuna has a magical bola which she can use to break ice, attack enemies and activate spirit markings for the Fox to summon.

The games art style is beautiful and has a very nice 3D art style in a side scroller that makes the game look very clean with it use of colours. Even though the game is set in Alaska it sets the scenes beautifully with the backgrounds adding the vibrant colours and the foreground showing the Alaskan wilderness. Even though the use of whites is quite abundant the use of the blues in the ice and the dark water breaks it up well. The game tells the story in an old cave painting like art style that complements the games setting well and doesn't feel out of place.

The games mechanics are very similar to a game like Limbo but adds another level with the inclusion of the two playable characters and local Co-Op. The local Co-Op is a nice addition to the game that is rarely seen in many modern games. Because the game has a very casual experience it is a game that would be good to play alongside a younger audience. Its puzzle mechanics start of very simple to get the player use to the mechanics but get harder and requires multiple teaming of the mechanics to overcome. An interesting part of the game worth mentioning is the winds that you can encounter, sometimes you will have to brace for the winds so you will not get blown back into your possible death on the other hand it can also be used to help you scale obstacles. This is an interesting inclusion plays very nicely into the environment set up by the game.

Never Alone is a very artistic take on the platformer genre that offers a unique story and playstyle that when teamed with local Co-Op it makes the game a very enjoyable experience. The environment is harsh and unforgiving but you can't help but love the art style, it really pulls you in and makes it enjoyable to look around at both the background and foreground. A younger audience will love this title and will find playing with their friend or parents an enjoyable experience.

reviewText:
This game reminded me a lot of Journey, except with greater emphasis on the story and interaction between two main characters. The game starts off as a fairly simple platformer, running, jumping and avoiding gusts of wind, but as the story progresses you get more actions for both characters adding very interesting movement puzzles. I played this single player and to that end it's limited as the AI can get troublesome in addition to have to switch characters rapidly between timed events. I would highly recommend playing this with someone else as that is where the game shines. Figuring out the puzzles together and working with different abilities is very fun and rewarding.

The story is also very engrossing like an old fairy tale. You also get glimpses into the native Alaskan lifestyle both past and present with Cultural Insights" which are unlocked minute or so segments which tell you about their history and culture. These usually have to do with part of the game you unlock them in and I found interesting and not distracting from the game itself.

Graphics and sound are both spot on. The art syle looks amazing and creates some very beautiful landscapes. Equally the sound effects and music help bring you to that cold wintery land feeling."
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This game caught my eye during a summer sale. I was browsing through some new releases and decided to purchase it. And as usual, it sat in the back of my steam library until I dusted it off, installed it and started playing.

My first impression of the game was the title screen, with its dark, snowy camp site. And then the title fades in on the screen. Kisima Ingitchuna. I was exited. The actual game begins with a story told through a traditional art form, which is a nice way to start off. In fact, this game itself is basically a story, told through the means of a platformer-style game.
I will not spoil the story here, because it is a good one, and you should hear it for yourself. :)

The game allows you to control two characters. Nuna and the Fox. It can be played with two players (similarly to Brothers), but I was playing it by my self, so I just switched between the two. Nuna can climb ladders and move heavy objects, while The Fox can crawl through tiny spaces and inch up walls. The Fox's biggest feature however, is that he can communicate with spirits. The spirits take form of something in the level and help you traverse the level as Nuna. The contrast of the two make for good gameplay. My only complaint with playing by yourself, is that the AI can be tricky sometimes. The computer-controlled character might jump off and force you to restart the puzzle. While it only happened occasionally, it was still annoying.

The game looks and sounds great. It has a fitting soundtrack that picks up with certain effects, depending on what your doing in the game, which is a nice touch. The graphics have a nice contrast of white and dark, following very closely to Alaska. There are places in the game where colors pop! For example: in one section of the game the Northern lights come down and take the form of little worm-like spirits. They look really cool in the dark of night, and serve the game well.

So, this game has a great soundtrack, nice graphics and solid gameplay... What more could you ask for? Well, the only REAL downside to this game is the amount of bugs. There are some movement bugs and graphical hiccups throughout.

So, to recap:

Pros:
- Good Story
- Enjoyable Gameplay
- Clean Visuals

Cons:
- Minor Bugs
- A bit Short
- $15 Price Tag (I would wait for a sale)

This game is very good. I enjoyed myself throughout, and have very small complaints. I recommend it to everyone.

Tj's Score: 7/10


-Tj

Edit: I have completed this game 100% and have all the achievements and collectables.

reviewText:
Never Alone isn't just any old platformer; it's an atmospheric adventure.

You're thrown into the role of a little girl on a quest to non-violently avenge and protect her village. You've got your trusty bola, your adorable fox, and your mad platforming skills. There's a beautiful world to explore as you progress through the game, but an even more beautiful culture to learn about as you overcome obstacles and discover secrets.

The scenery and graphics are phenominal! When I saw that sheen on some ice in the foreground I was hit with an immediate sense of awe. The wind, snow, water, trees, use of blur on elements in the background which directly affect elements in the foreground—everything was done just so well!

The premise for the game allows for the puzzles to be very interesting and very reverent toward the culture Never Alone is trying to represent. None feel cheap or lazy, but there are some minor bugs that can sometimes cause you to believe you aren't on the right track, when, in reality, you were actually a step away from the solution.

The storytelling is extremely well done! There are so few games that really put your journey into perspective like this game has. It makes you realize just how far you've progressed, making the ending all the more rewarding.

Never Alone is an example of how to create a telling experience without sacrificing the integrity of technical expectations from modern video games. It provides genuinely enjoyable platforming while making you ponder and admire the world, story, and culture it's established and portrayed throughout your adventure.

Kudos to anyone to finds this game in their library.

reviewText:
Never Alone was a great experience, and if I could classify it as something other than atmospheric puzzle-platformer, it would be as an interactive documentary and view into the cultural aspects that shape the Inupiaq people and their beliefs and way of life. The story itself is relatively simple: It is about a girl, Nuna, and her fox companion traveling to find the source of a mysterious blizzard, Since it is based off of a commonly told story, it's understandable there wouldn't be a strong emphasis on story twists or even on character development. It really does shine in incorporating a lot of different aspects of the Inupiaq culture into the game, however, and with this artistic choice it sets itself apart from other puzzle platformers. I enjoyed seeing a female protagonist, and a protagonist from a culture you would not usually see within video games. The art inspiration they drew from the art of the Inupiaq is also very apparent and delightfully different from what you might usually see.

Gameplay-wise, as a puzzle platformer you control either Nuna or the fox (with one person controlling each character in co-op). A lot of puzzles will require coordination of both, and the use of the spirits added a very interesting element to the gameplay by allowing you to manipulate and change how to traverse (this is apparent later in the game). I played with a controller, and the input felt very smooth, though I heard that keyboard users may find it a bit more difficult to play. It can be a bit confusing playing by yourself and forgetting which character you're controlling, but this is very minor compared to the overall scope of the game. However, when I was not controlling a character, they sometimes moved unfavorably, resulting in my having to restart from the last checkpoint, but to my understanding a patch was rolled out prior to this review that fixed this. There were also some glitches where characters got stuck in walls, which I think may have been fixed, but as of the time of this writing is something to keep in mind before purchasing.

I enjoyed my experience, and if you like learning about new cultures and some neat art design and puzzles, then I recommend picking this game up. If anything, it allowed a brief but insightful look into the culture of a people normally not represented in many works.

reviewText:
What's it about?
Never Alone (Kisima Ingithuna) is a 2.5D puzzle platformer based around Alaska Native stories and culture. You play as Nuna, a young Alaska Native girl, and Fox, her four-legged vulpine friend (I call him Pat) as they journey across the tundra and ice floes of Alaska in their quest to uncover the source of the savage blizzards that are threatening their very existance.

How does it play?
As previously mentioned, the game is a 2.5D platformer, by which I mean it takes place on a 2D plane with backgrounds in full 3D. It can be played in local co-op, with one player controlling Nuna and the other handling Fox, or single-player with the player switching between the characters at the touch of a button.

The puzzles are not too difficult, though they do take a few tries to get right, and they use the environment well. Each character has their own set of skills that you uncover as you progress through the game. Nuna can push heavy objects and throw a magical bola to destroy ice barriers, while Fox can scramble up high walls, perform wall jumps and get the spirits of the land to help you out.

The game has some AI problems, with the character you're not controlling sometimes doing some stupid things like casually hopping off a platform or forgetting to brace in the wind. These problems were apparently worse at launch and a patch has since addressed some of the issues, but it is not perfect. The platforming also feels a little bit heavy, which makes sense when you consider the characters are not superbeings. I prefer platforming to be more dynamic, but this is just personal taste. Nuna's bola is also awkward to aim when using a controller, since you have to tilt the right thumbstick away from and then towards your target. I didn't play with mouse and keyboard, but the game apparently works just fine with them.

How does it look?
Never Alone runs on the Unity engine, so it should run just fine on any system. Its a lovely-looking game, with glistening ice and whirling snow bringing the harsh landscape to life, aided by good-quality textures. Animation quality is somewhat lacking, but the character models have a pleasingly cartoony look to them and fur is pretty well rendered on Nuna's coat and Fox's body.

Cutscenes between stages are animated in a traditional native art style, which made me think of shadow puppet plays. While I respect what they were trying to achieve, I ultimately thought that these looked a lot worse than the game itself, and actually detatched me from the experience. I think the cutscenes would have been better had they been done in the game engine but, again, this is down to personal preference.

How does it sound?
The narrator delivers the story in his native tongue (I don't know what it's called, forgive my ignorance) with a voice that seems to carry the wisdom of thousands of years. It is not reactive in the way that Bastion was, but does a good job of giving relevance to your actions and progress. The music grants the game a feeling of loneliness and isolation that makes me think of the Phendrana Drifts zone in the Gamecube classic Metroid Prime, and the howling winds of the blizzards are brilliantly realised. You can almost feel the biting cold as each gust of wind threatens to send you flying over an edge or aides you in crossing a wide chasm.

Long story short
Never Alone is a lovely game. It is only a couple of hours long, yet it seems to be just the right length; not outstaying its welcome but not leaving the player gagging for more. The AI could have done with just a little more tweaking and a couple of glitches could be fixed (there were a couple of times when I clipped through a wall or across a gap), but the experience of the game is one to savour. There are several videos that give you some insight into the Alaska Native culture, which you can view ingame after finding them (I recommend you wait until you've finished the game before viewing them). Overall, Never Alone is by no means perfect, but is a heartwarming tale, ideal for the cold winter nights ahead.

reviewText:
TL:DR - Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna) is a beautifully done, artistic piece of Iñupiat culture. (Pros/Cons Below)

Never Alone is best played with two people, but still plays very well solo since many of the puzzles only require one character to do something at a time, and the ai controlling the other character is intelligent (for the most part). The dynamic between the two characters is worth mentioning, since both have different but complimentary playstyles; the fox being more nimple at climbing or crawling through small spaces, whereas the girl can climb ladders, move objects, or use her weapon to break ice.
In addition, Never Alone shares the Iñupiat culture in a tasteful and powerful way. Short cultural videos - that display the beautiful alaskan landscape, and the lifestyle of the Iñupiat people - can be unlocked in-game by encountering lore owls. The gameplay/storyline itself is also rich with Iñupiat folklore; such as spirits helping you traverse perilous terrain or dwarf-like characters causing mischief.
All in all a beautifully done game which is not only fun to play, but teaches you something in the process.

------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------
PROS:
----------
- Smart & intense gameplay
+ Interesting and moderately difficult puzzles
+ Occasional fast-paced action sequences
+ Minor map exploration elements

- Great for co-op
- Stunning visuals
- In-depth cultural experience

CONS:
----------
- Occasional gameplay/graphical glitches
- Short storyline
------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText:
So I just finished Never Alone, which is more or less an Inupiat (one of the northern Alaska/Canada native cultural groups) fable set around some light platforming.

The fable part is cool as hell. Absolutely wonderful art and audio direction paired with Inupiat-language subtitled narration is transportive in a way that actually deserves the word. I grew up in the northern plains of the US (Minnesota) and the feel of cold, winter, and blizzards are conveyed in Never Alone in a way that I've never experienced in a game before. It's worth the ($15) price of admission for that alone.

The platforming, on the other hand, ranges from reasonable" in the dead-easy first two-thirds of the game to "unbearably janky" in the final three sequences. I made it through thanks to a checkpoint system that would be generous to a fault in a game with mechanics that aren't actively offensive
date: but I would have gladly hit an autoplay button to experience the story and the ambiance so as not to have to suffer through the awful gameplay in those later sections.\n\nThat said
recommended: I'd recommend playing it through rather than watching it on YouTube if only to enjoy the production values and to be put into the story a little more
hoursPlayed: at least in the early sections. Plus you unlock "cultural insights" which are slickly produced live-action segments that illustrate some fashion of Inupiat culture
voteText: history
helpfulPercent: lifestyle
votesHelpful: and suchlike.\n\nIt's not long (~6 hours it took me
votesTotal: maybe?) and best enjoyed with a co-op partner (switching characters during timed-platforming sections is one of the larger issues with the gameplay
votesFunny: though it's not quite as irritating as the unresponsive movement and janky collision).\n\nDefinitely recommended
commentsCount: though I can't fathom the universe in which this gets a 10/10."

reviewText: I can't help but compare it to Limbo, since they are both really similar in how they play, and I can't think of anything else I have played that also fits into a similar catagory. If you liked Limbo, you'll probably like this, The gameplay, controls and puzzle designs aren't as polsihed in this game, but they're similar, and everything that I love in Limbo, the environment, art style and story, are all really strong in this game as well. The controlling of two characters mechanic is fine, and at least for the first half of the game I found it quite enjoyable, but without spoiling much, it changes about 1/2 to 2/3 of the way through where it suddenly for me became a lot more frustrating and I died a lot without really feeling like I was to blame because of poor controls and just irritating design choices, and that's really my biggest critisism with the game. I still enjoyed it enough to recommend it, not strongly, but the art, environment and story are good enough that I would say you should experience the game for yourself.
